page.title: 08ST.SWITHUN'S LEADENHAM
page.content: Our village Church at Leadenham built in the 14th Century replaced the earlier Church referred to in the first Domesday Book.A fine lychgate gives entry to a lovely churchyard making a superb setting for a beautiful Church built of Ancaster stone.The spire soars up from a square tower. Inside,the first impression is of an uncluttered place of worship. Seating in the pews is for 320,and the choir seats 24.The chancel is a special feature of the Church.The reredos and roof were decorated by the artist Augustus Welby Pugin.The east window has some very old Flemish glass in the triple rose of "Christ in Majesty".The other stained glass windows,installed in memory of families complete the picture.The Church clock,a flat bed movement given in 1861,strikes the hours and quarters
